original: Hetuñca nahetuñca dhammaṁ paṭicca nahetu dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. Hetuñca nahetuñca🔽dhammaṁ paṭicca nanahetu dhammo uppajjati hetupaccayā. Hetuñca nahetuñca dhammaṁ🔽paṭicca nahetu ca nanahetu ca dhammā uppajjanti hetupaccayā. (Saṅkhittaṁ.)

translated: With a cause and a cause-free state as condition, a cause-free state arises, by way of root-cause condition. With a cause and a cause-free state as condition, a cause-possessing state arises, by way of root-cause condition. With a cause and a cause-free state as condition, a cause-free and a cause-possessing state arise, by way of root-cause condition. (Abbreviated.)

original: Hetuyā nava, ārammaṇe nava …pe… avigate nava. (Sahajātavārampi …pe… sampayuttavārampi paṭiccavārasadisaṁ.)
analyzed: hetuyā nava ārammaṇe nava pe avigate nava sahajāta vārampi pe sampayutta vārampi paṭicca vāra sadisa
translated: With a cause as condition, nine. With an object as condition, nine. … With an absence as condition, nine. (The section on the origination of the simultaneous condition is to be elaborated in the same way as the section on condition.)

original: Hetu-ārammaṇa🔽Hetu dhammo nahetussa dhammassa hetupaccayena paccayo … tīṇi.
analyzed: hetu ārammaṇa  hetu dhammaḥ na hetussa dhammassa hetu paccayena paccayaḥ tīṇi
translated: With a cause as object🔽A cause is a condition, by way of root-cause condition, for a cause-free state … for three.

original: Hetu dhammo nahetussa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo … tīṇi.🔽Nahetu dhammo nanahetussa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo … tīṇi.
analyzed: hetu dhammaḥ na hetussa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ tīṇi  na hetu dhammaḥ na na hetussa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ tīṇi
translated: A cause is a condition, by way of object condition, for a cause-free state … for three.🔽A cause-free state is a condition, by way of object condition, for a cause-possessing state … for three.

original: Hetu ca nahetu ca dhammā nahetussa dhammassa ārammaṇapaccayena paccayo … tīṇi. (Saṅkhittaṁ.)
analyzed: hetu ca na hetu ca dhammā na hetussa dhammassa ārammaṇa paccayena paccayaḥ tīṇi
translated: A cause and a cause-free state are conditions, by way of object condition, for a cause-free state … for three. (Abbreviated.)

original: Hetuyā tīṇi, ārammaṇe nava …pe… upanissaye nava, purejāte pacchājāte tīṇi, āsevane🔽nava, kamme tīṇi, vipāke nava, āhāre tīṇi, indriye nava, jhāne tīṇi, magge sampayutte
analyzed: hetuyā tīṇi ārammaṇe nava pe upanissaye nava purejāte pacchājāte tīṇi āsevane  nava kamme tīṇi vipāke nava āhāre tīṇi indriye nava jhāne tīṇi magge sampayutte
translated: There are three lines of reasoning in respect of cause, nine in respect of object, … nine in respect of prenascence, nine in respect of postnascence, three in respect of kamma, nine in respect of nutriment, three in respect of faculty, nine in respect of path, nine in respect of association,

original: nava, vippayutte pañca …pe… avigate nava. (Pañhāvārampi evaṁ vitthāretabbaṁ.)
analyzed: nava vippayutte pañca pe avigate nava pañhāvāram pi evam vitthāretabba
translated: Three lines of the following type are to be written for each of the remaining terms: “In the case of cause, there are three; in the case of object, nine … in the case of decisive support, nine; in the case of prenascence, three; in the case of postnascence, three; in the case of nutriment, three; in the case of faculty, nine; in the case of jhāna, three; in the case of path, three; in the case of association, nine; in the case of dissociation, five … in the case of nongreed, nine.” The section consisting of questions should also be expanded in each case in the same way.
